urn:contentItem:58RS-VMG1-JD2T-F1J2-00000-00Skilling's Sliced Sentence; Surviving In Style; Bernanke Slammed for Bond Buying Statement; Michael Dell vs Carl Icahn Battles in Wall Street;2013-06-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:28ZLexisNexisSkilling's Sliced Sentence; Surviving In Style; Bernanke Slammed for Bond Buying Statement; Michael Dell vs Carl Icahn Battles in Wall Street;

MELISSA FRANCIS, FBN ANCHOR: They said Bernanke never should've opened his mouth this week. With the fed making a financial mess, how to prepare with what is coming next.

Plus, surviving the apocalypse in style. A California developer is opening the world's largest doomsday shelter and resort. Where do I make my reservation? The man behind it joins us.

And who lost "Money" today? One of America's top CEO, it is so much money, it would make John B. Rockefeller cry. Stay tuned to find out who it is.

Because even when they say t is not, it is always about "Money."

It is the end of a very tumultuous week on Wall Street and it is time for some serious crisis management for the fed. So, you are entering the spin zone. Ben Bernanke is getting slam for statements this week about the possibility of easing off the bond buying program which came just two days of the fed chairman was basically fired on the Charlie Rose show. I don't know if you saw this, a lot of moving pieces but we want you to know what you have to do right now to protect yourself in the midst of all of it.

Joining me now is Barron's senior editor, Jack Hough and Pat Howell, CEO of Howell financial group. Welcome back to the show.

Jack, let me start with you. Have the wheels come off the fed here? I mean, it has been quite a week for those guys.

JACK HOUGH, SENIOR EDITOR, BARRON: I'm not sure what the dissent is about. I mean, are we supposed to keep interest rates near zero forever? I mean, at this point, you are trading off this much improvement in the economy versus this much distortion of every kind of asset class investors have a choice of. It is time, isn't it?

FRANCIS: It is time. But that is not really what we're talking about. I mean, what we are talking about is sort of the chaos that ensued this week. For example, I mean, let me play you the sound bite. President Obama basically fired Ben Bernanke in Charlie Rose. And we will get both your reactions on the other side. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think Ben Bernanke has done an outstanding job. Ben Bernanke is a little bit like Bob Mueller, the head of the FBI where he has already stayed a lot longer than he wanted or he was supposed to. But, I think --

CHARLIE ROSE, TV HOST: But if he wanted to be reappointed, you would reappoint him?

OBAMA: He has been outstanding partner along with the White House.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: What? I mean, that is not really a ringing endorsement. Pat, that is like somebody saying, you know, how is your husband? You are like, well, he has been outstanding partner until now.

PATRICIA POWELL, CEO, POWELL FINANCIAL GROUP: Anybody can be a loose cannon, it is just odd it is the president of the United States.

FRANCIS: Is he a loose cannon or was that on purpose? I mean, don't know. There is a lot of negativity there.

POWELL: He is making some telegraphing things too. He is not going to Jackson hole, you know, that was a little odd. I mean, he has been telegraphing things. And a lot of people say that he is tired, this has been exhausting thing, and it was not really -- this is now what he had in mind when he became chairman of the fed.

HOUGH: He was looking at his shoes when he said that, right?

FRANCIS: Right.

HOUGH: I'm not a body language expert, but that says stayed.

FRANCIS: He stayed a lot longer than he was supposed to or he wanted to. I mean, that is pretty harsh. So then, it is not surprising that Ben Bernanke comes out, rocks the boat a bit. I mean, they are all over the place. You have James Bullard, Ben coming out today saying, well maybe, you know, we are going t have more combination down the road if we need it. Basically, going against everything that Ben Bernanke said, which is sort of all over the map. Where does that leave investors?

HOUGH: It is unusual to see a special press release like that with a sort of dissenting view. And I think it is already a tumultuous time for the market. I don't think there's any kind of financial Armageddon. I mean, where people are getting crazy about losing a few percent in the stock market. Keep in mind the market is double in nearly, you know, in about four years, and treasury rates are up (INAUDIBLE), were 2.5 percent for the average over the past 50 years, it is over six percent. So we don't have skyrocketing interest rates something like that.

FRANCIS: It says that the whole point is we need these guys. I mean, they are doing -- they have done policy that we have never seen before in our lives. So, we need them to dismount in the cleanest way possible her and get out of it. So far just this week it has been utter chaos.

My favorite comment because the twitter universe and online to block its fear was alive, with all of these different machination during the week. I love Lawrence McDonald tweeted, somebody that a lot of us follow, he is on TV all the time. He said job opening, portfolio manager need for $3.5 trillion, 70-tons leverage Hedge Fund unlimited borrow, no marked market, see Federal Reserve.

Does not inspire confidence? I mean, everybody is joking about what is going on. It does tell you don't have a lot of confidence of what is going on.

POWELL: Well, nobody here has confidence because we don't know how this is going to be around. But, it is so much better that they are telling us this stuff. We don't want to invest blindly. We don't want to have another secret.

FRANCIS: They telling us, what though? They are telling us all different things. I mean, Bullard says we could ease more. Ben Bernanke says we are getting out, President Obama says he is fired, telling us what?

POWELL: Well, Bernanke started, I think, on the 22nd of May by giving us the first inkling that there thinking about chasing, and I think in this particular -- the comments this week really dealt with the fact that we are creating a plan to taper. This is a very good thing. It is so much better to have a plan than to be shooting from the hips which was not good.

FRANCIS: So, how do we all set ourselves up for this because this is the take away that we want for our audience here? It means that interest rates are going up, maybe, my thought is give anything interest-rate sensitive whether it is an adjustable mortgage or it is credit card rates you want to keep an eye on that, maybe it is a great time in real estate to transact whether you are a buyer or a seller. I mean, if you are a buyer, this is probably as good as the rates are going to be. If you are seller, you may want to transact because it is the most money that a buyer is going to have. What do you think?

POWELL: Buyers may start rushing in because they have been sitting back waiting to see what is going to happen, now they saw a real choice. If interest rates go up, every point that goes up they lose purchasing power or borrowing power. So, it can push the real estate market, actually, up in the short run.

FRANCIS: In the short run. In the long run, I mean, Jack, would you agree with that? In the long run, it is bad for the real estate market because higher interest rates make it tougher.

HOUGH: I'm on sure there is anyone here is on the fence right now, that waiting for a little less of the mortgage rate before they buy, I mean, that ship has sailed. But I think in terms of investors right now, you hold onto some extra cash because there's a possibility both stocks and bonds are going to be weak at the same time. We don't a lynch how an interesting piece of research what they said. Right now, inflations is actually coming down and interest rates are going up, which is a rarity. It happened in 1994, at that time tech stocks outperformed, utilities got hurt, they were recommending the same thing right now.

FRANCIS: Interesting point of view.

All right, thanks to both of you. Good stuff.

HOUGH: Thank you.

FRANCIS: Time now for today's fuel gauge report. China and Russia signing $270 billion oil deal. It is one of the biggest in history. Rosneft, Russian's state owned oil company will double supplies to China. It could reach up to 900,000 barrels per day. That is according to Vladimir Putin. The 25 year deal makes chin China the biggest customer for Russian oil.

U.S. gasoline demand for May fell to a 13 year low. That is according to the American Petroleum Institute. Demand slipped by 3.3 percent to about 8.7 million barrels per day.

And Oil futures is getting smacked for a second session, a stronger U.S. dollar largely fueling oil decline. It posted its biggest two-day drop in a year losing about 4.5 percent. Crude settled at $93.69 a barrel. Big move on the week.

All right, up next, Michael Dell versus Carl Icahn, it is the face-off only the power of money could create. We are going to tell you how it is turning personal now.

Plus, the reason the government has gotten so good at spying on you is because it is coaching top talent from Silicon Valley. Maybe you didn't know that. We got details on the stunning revelation in the NSA scandal.

More "Money" coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: The battle between two Wall Street titans is getting bigger and personal, by the way. Michael Dell now launching a personal pitch to buy out his ubiquitous company, and pushed Icahn's offer out of the way, but will it deliver or well Icahn when out? It is all about the power of "Money."

Here to weigh in is "Wall Street Journal" business editor, Dennis Berman and Jonas Max Ferris at MaxFunds.com.

Great to have you both on the show.

Dennis, let me start with you. This is battle of the titans. I mean, these are two enormous egos out there, so how do you size of the whole think?

DENNIS BERMAN, BUSINESS EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: I see Dell winning, Icahn losing.

FRANCIS: Really? How come?

BERMAN: Simple reason. The best chance for Dell to beaten was a potential rival bid from another private equity firm. Carl Icahn, at this point, he could do a lot of great noise and smoke and a lot of activity, but when it comes down to it the shareholder will have to say that he wants to take this offer or do we not? And right now, given the market where they are, they are probably going to take the offer of $14 per share.

RANDOLPH: I see the value on this product.

FRANCIS: You do?

RANDOLPH: This will be even (ph) my secret weapon. You will buy a $50 million apartment. I'm going to start using this with my client.

(LAUGHTER)

RANDOLPH: I mean, I don't see why not. If this actually became an approved Apple accessory. So --

FRANCIS: What? Really?

RANDOLPH: It's kind of amazing.

FRANCIS: There should be a breathalyzer attached to it.

(CROSSTALK)

RANDOLPH: They're going to come up with that.

PRABHAKAR: Right.

RANDOLPH: And if you go on the website, the pink ones are the ones that have sold out first. I'm just waiting for the camouflage.

FRANCIS: How much is the cost? Does anybody know?

RANDOLPH: I think it's about $140.

FRANCIS: Wow! That's amazing. Well, there's a Christmas gift.

All right. So, the big baby news of the week, a bizarre name given. Reality princess, Kim Kardashian and rapper baby daddy, Kanye West, have chosen the name North, North, for their baby girl. Think about that for a second. The baby's name is Northwest, no middle name. I mean, they're running this child's life or they giving it direction.

PRABHAKAR: All right. We can safely assume that it's not a fan of One Direction, right, the band?

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: OK. All right. I like that. That was good. Jarrod, what do you think about this?

RANDOLPH: The middle name should be Southeast. So, it's north, south, east, west. I mean, I actually can't believe we're talking about this right now.

(LAUGHTER)

RANDOLPH: But think about it, there were other names that could have come up with. Lampshade, soda can. I mean, they could have named it anything.

FRANCIS: Seven, Pepsi. I don't know. All those --

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: One of the worst names ever.

PRABHAKAR: I like the east and west. Wasn't east and west --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: And we wrap up the week. Our own Tom Sullivan has some doubts about the direction of our economy. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TOM SULLIVAN, FOX BUSINESS: Something isn't right about the economy. I'm trying to be positive, and yes, the economy has expanded every quarter going back to 2009. But it's consistently weak growth. The job market, it's also improving, but not enough to soak up all of the new people that are coming into the job market, the young grads and immigrants. And housing, it seems to be doing better. In fact, in some places, there's another price bubble growing.

But, it's because there are two few homes for sale and that's largely because whopping (ph) number, 44 percent of homeowners are either under water or they don't have enough equity to pay a realtor to sell their home, so they sit. And it's the same number, 44 percent of people who told CNN in a poll this week that they are worse off economically now than compared to just one year ago.

The huge portion of the country is still hurting. The markets are nervous about the fed slowing down its artificial pumping of the economy. I get that, but even though I don't like what the fed is done, I don't see the fed making any big changes, and I don't see this fragile economy jumping out of its sick bed anytime soon.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Well, that's true. Thanks, Tom. Be sure to watch "The Tom Sullivan Show" this weekend. You can catch it at 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on Saturday, and on Sunday at 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. Happy Friday, everyone. Thanks to both of you for joining us. Have a great weekend. I'll see you back here on Monday.

END

MELISSA FRANCIS, FBN ANCHOR: They said Bernanke never should've opened his mouth this week. With the fed making a financial mess, how to prepare with what is coming next.

Plus, surviving the apocalypse in style. A California developer is opening the world's largest doomsday shelter and resort. Where do I make my reservation? The man behind it joins us.

And who lost "Money" today? One of America's top CEO, it is so much money, it would make John B. Rockefeller cry. Stay tuned to find out who it is.

Because even when they say t is not, it is always about "Money."

It is the end of a very tumultuous week on Wall Street and it is time for some serious crisis management for the fed. So, you are entering the spin zone. Ben Bernanke is getting slam for statements this week about the possibility of easing off the bond buying program which came just two days of the fed chairman was basically fired on the Charlie Rose show. I don't know if you saw this, a lot of moving pieces but we want you to know what you have to do right now to protect yourself in the midst of all of it.

Joining me now is Barron's senior editor, Jack Hough and Pat Howell, CEO of Howell financial group. Welcome back to the show.

Jack, let me start with you. Have the wheels come off the fed here? I mean, it has been quite a week for those guys.

JACK HOUGH, SENIOR EDITOR, BARRON: I'm not sure what the dissent is about. I mean, are we supposed to keep interest rates near zero forever? I mean, at this point, you are trading off this much improvement in the economy versus this much distortion of every kind of asset class investors have a choice of. It is time, isn't it?

FRANCIS: It is time. But that is not really what we're talking about. I mean, what we are talking about is sort of the chaos that ensued this week. For example, I mean, let me play you the sound bite. President Obama basically fired Ben Bernanke in Charlie Rose. And we will get both your reactions on the other side. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think Ben Bernanke has done an outstanding job. Ben Bernanke is a little bit like Bob Mueller, the head of the FBI where he has already stayed a lot longer than he wanted or he was supposed to. But, I think --

CHARLIE ROSE, TV HOST: But if he wanted to be reappointed, you would reappoint him?

OBAMA: He has been outstanding partner along with the White House.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: What? I mean, that is not really a ringing endorsement. Pat, that is like somebody saying, you know, how is your husband? You are like, well, he has been outstanding partner until now.

PATRICIA POWELL, CEO, POWELL FINANCIAL GROUP: Anybody can be a loose cannon, it is just odd it is the president of the United States.

FRANCIS: Is he a loose cannon or was that on purpose? I mean, don't know. There is a lot of negativity there.

POWELL: He is making some telegraphing things too. He is not going to Jackson hole, you know, that was a little odd. I mean, he has been telegraphing things. And a lot of people say that he is tired, this has been exhausting thing, and it was not really -- this is now what he had in mind when he became chairman of the fed.

HOUGH: He was looking at his shoes when he said that, right?

FRANCIS: Right.

HOUGH: I'm not a body language expert, but that says stayed.

FRANCIS: He stayed a lot longer than he was supposed to or he wanted to. I mean, that is pretty harsh. So then, it is not surprising that Ben Bernanke comes out, rocks the boat a bit. I mean, they are all over the place. You have James Bullard, Ben coming out today saying, well maybe, you know, we are going t have more combination down the road if we need it. Basically, going against everything that Ben Bernanke said, which is sort of all over the map. Where does that leave investors?

HOUGH: It is unusual to see a special press release like that with a sort of dissenting view. And I think it is already a tumultuous time for the market. I don't think there's any kind of financial Armageddon. I mean, where people are getting crazy about losing a few percent in the stock market. Keep in mind the market is double in nearly, you know, in about four years, and treasury rates are up (INAUDIBLE), were 2.5 percent for the average over the past 50 years, it is over six percent. So we don't have skyrocketing interest rates something like that.

FRANCIS: It says that the whole point is we need these guys. I mean, they are doing -- they have done policy that we have never seen before in our lives. So, we need them to dismount in the cleanest way possible her and get out of it. So far just this week it has been utter chaos.

My favorite comment because the twitter universe and online to block its fear was alive, with all of these different machination during the week. I love Lawrence McDonald tweeted, somebody that a lot of us follow, he is on TV all the time. He said job opening, portfolio manager need for $3.5 trillion, 70-tons leverage Hedge Fund unlimited borrow, no marked market, see Federal Reserve.

Does not inspire confidence? I mean, everybody is joking about what is going on. It does tell you don't have a lot of confidence of what is going on.

POWELL: Well, nobody here has confidence because we don't know how this is going to be around. But, it is so much better that they are telling us this stuff. We don't want to invest blindly. We don't want to have another secret.

FRANCIS: They telling us, what though? They are telling us all different things. I mean, Bullard says we could ease more. Ben Bernanke says we are getting out, President Obama says he is fired, telling us what?

POWELL: Well, Bernanke started, I think, on the 22nd of May by giving us the first inkling that there thinking about chasing, and I think in this particular -- the comments this week really dealt with the fact that we are creating a plan to taper. This is a very good thing. It is so much better to have a plan than to be shooting from the hips which was not good.

FRANCIS: So, how do we all set ourselves up for this because this is the take away that we want for our audience here? It means that interest rates are going up, maybe, my thought is give anything interest-rate sensitive whether it is an adjustable mortgage or it is credit card rates you want to keep an eye on that, maybe it is a great time in real estate to transact whether you are a buyer or a seller. I mean, if you are a buyer, this is probably as good as the rates are going to be. If you are seller, you may want to transact because it is the most money that a buyer is going to have. What do you think?

POWELL: Buyers may start rushing in because they have been sitting back waiting to see what is going to happen, now they saw a real choice. If interest rates go up, every point that goes up they lose purchasing power or borrowing power. So, it can push the real estate market, actually, up in the short run.

FRANCIS: In the short run. In the long run, I mean, Jack, would you agree with that? In the long run, it is bad for the real estate market because higher interest rates make it tougher.

HOUGH: I'm on sure there is anyone here is on the fence right now, that waiting for a little less of the mortgage rate before they buy, I mean, that ship has sailed. But I think in terms of investors right now, you hold onto some extra cash because there's a possibility both stocks and bonds are going to be weak at the same time. We don't a lynch how an interesting piece of research what they said. Right now, inflations is actually coming down and interest rates are going up, which is a rarity. It happened in 1994, at that time tech stocks outperformed, utilities got hurt, they were recommending the same thing right now.

FRANCIS: Interesting point of view.

All right, thanks to both of you. Good stuff.

HOUGH: Thank you.

FRANCIS: Time now for today's fuel gauge report. China and Russia signing $270 billion oil deal. It is one of the biggest in history. Rosneft, Russian's state owned oil company will double supplies to China. It could reach up to 900,000 barrels per day. That is according to Vladimir Putin. The 25 year deal makes chin China the biggest customer for Russian oil.

U.S. gasoline demand for May fell to a 13 year low. That is according to the American Petroleum Institute. Demand slipped by 3.3 percent to about 8.7 million barrels per day.

And Oil futures is getting smacked for a second session, a stronger U.S. dollar largely fueling oil decline. It posted its biggest two-day drop in a year losing about 4.5 percent. Crude settled at $93.69 a barrel. Big move on the week.

All right, up next, Michael Dell versus Carl Icahn, it is the face-off only the power of money could create. We are going to tell you how it is turning personal now.

Plus, the reason the government has gotten so good at spying on you is because it is coaching top talent from Silicon Valley. Maybe you didn't know that. We got details on the stunning revelation in the NSA scandal.

More "Money" coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: The battle between two Wall Street titans is getting bigger and personal, by the way. Michael Dell now launching a personal pitch to buy out his ubiquitous company, and pushed Icahn's offer out of the way, but will it deliver or well Icahn when out? It is all about the power of "Money."

Here to weigh in is "Wall Street Journal" business editor, Dennis Berman and Jonas Max Ferris at MaxFunds.com.

Great to have you both on the show.

Dennis, let me start with you. This is battle of the titans. I mean, these are two enormous egos out there, so how do you size of the whole think?

DENNIS BERMAN, BUSINESS EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: I see Dell winning, Icahn losing.

FRANCIS: Really? How come?

BERMAN: Simple reason. The best chance for Dell to beaten was a potential rival bid from another private equity firm. Carl Icahn, at this point, he could do a lot of great noise and smoke and a lot of activity, but when it comes down to it the shareholder will have to say that he wants to take this offer or do we not? And right now, given the market where they are, they are probably going to take the offer of $14 per share.

FRANCIS: So Jonas, what do you think? I mean, his basically saying Silver Lake wins the day because, of course, that too smacky (ph) Michael Dell?

JONAS MAX FERRIS, MARKET WATCHER, MAXFUNDS.COM: Because I think people would rather side with the guy who started the company in his dorm room then some Wall Street raider. I just don't think that that is -- that guy is going to fix it.

FRANCIS: The guy has started the company in his dorm room, but has kind of driven it into the ground, right?

FERRIS: Well, by that logic every tech CEO who isn't Apple or Samsung should be fired because they all missed the smart phone revolution. Go down the line, everybody screwed up. And the whole PC, this has come on land. That was original cornerstone of the business was assembling PC box. That is a dying business and it is easy to say, he missed the smart phone and pad revolution, yes, it is good. But everybody didn't because it is really hard to compete.

FRANCIS: I don't know. I mean, Dennis, right here you have his whole plan, Michael Dell's whole plan right here, for how he will turn the company around. And we were talking about this is the commercial break is that if he has this brilliance, why hasn't he done it already, why doesn't he do it while the company is public? I mean, just do it, you know. Why do you have to take (INAUDIBLE).

BERMAN: I think you make a really good point. I agree with you. And, if you read this and it doesn't take long because he doesn't write very much here you will be relatively uninspired by what with Michael dell has to say. You will be relatively uninspired by what Michael Dell has to say. It is what I would call problem. It is generic. It does not say anything.

But, whether he says anything here or not or whether Carl Icahn is the right person to be a part of dell, really, it doesn't matter is there's only one thing that matters, to shareholders want to accept the price for dell right now? There are no offers being the price of the stock is trading below the $14 offer. It the market that telling us that will probably be accepted. Although, it may not be easy at the moment.

FRANCIS: Jonas, if you are a shareholder -- but, are you, by the way?

FERRIS: We all own it through mutual funds indirectly. Directly, don't bow and very few people only this directly. It is not growth stock getting more and the public only owns like Apple directly users all along by --.

FRANCIS: So, would say, give me the $14 let me the hell out of the stock? So, I can just forget about Dell and go off.

FERRIS: Because I think Icahn is playing an a head start for proxy movie, who with all the movie with the executives try to pretend the company was worthless so they can buy the stock at a cheap price and then by putting the bad CEO in. That was the movie. I think that is what the spin is here, the Dell rule is down talking the stock so he could take it private.

FRANCIS: So you think it has more value than Roe (ph).

FERRIS: I do think so.

FRANCIS: Really? Why, what is so valuable?

FERRIS: Well, it is a long shot, but without the PC business, I think there is still an angle to be some sort of IBM asks more, you know, selling silver type in software company. It is not a huge growth opportunity, but I think there is something there that is more valuable than the current share price. That is a better price for a lot of non-Apple, Samsung companies today.

FRANCIS: What do you think, Dennis? Is that possible?

BERMAN: It is certainly possible. And this is that the fundamental complex. The real tension inside this management by IPOs, what does the guy at the top of the ladder know that I don't know that he shares with us? And should I trust him, or should I not?

Here is another great example. J. Crew, great company. We all know that company. It went private after the CEO basically forced and offer down his owned shareholder's growth. So, Jonas makes a fair point about the conflicts inherent in that those dynamics. But again, as it stands now, roughly 15 percent or so of shares are a lied against BBO (ph).

FRANCIS: But wait, but other than him knowing something we all don't, what would be his other reason for wanting to take it private?

FERRIS: I would say vanity. It is his business. He has got his name on it. It is hard to walk away. You don't want it to die. It is called Dell. It is not Microsoft, you know. It holds on Bill Gates' software. So, it is like there's a certain element where you want it to succeed.

FRANCIS: So, it is either vanity or he knows something we don't? Real quick before we go, what is your bet, vanity or he knows something we don't?

FERRIS: I think it is still worth more than it is. I do think all these tycoons, these are old, are going to go private at some point because --.

FRANCIS: So, he knows something we don't. That's how I'm going to interpret that.

Dennis, what do you think, vanity or he know something we don't?

BERMAN: I say the answer is both. But, in the end --

FRANCIS: How can it be both? Pick one.

BERMAN: Well, he is both vain and he knows something that we don't. Those can both motivations. In the end, the shareholders are going to bite because --.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: OK. Guys, you are fantastic, thank you.

BERMAN: Thank you.

FRANCIS: Coming up on "Money," if you knew facebook former chief security officer but feel like he has dropped off the radar, here is why. He is now working for the NSA and he is not alone. We will tell you how Silicon Valley is getting help to the government's prying eyes.

Plus, former Enron CEO, Jeff Skilling, hits 10 years, why he stop his prison sentence? And it could be a dream come true for white-collar criminals.

Stay right where you are and find out why.

Do you ever have too much "Money"?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Weather it is on Wall Street or Main Street, here is to make "Money" today.

Actually, I can start with who made money. Larry Ellison, the CEO of Oracle, lost so much money I have to do that one first. Oracle's latest earnings were a big disappointment on Wall Street. And as a result, the shares plunged more than nine percent today. So Larry Ellison owns 1.1 billion shares of Oracle. That means he lost $3.4 billion today, $3.4 billion. I had to put that in perspective. Ellison bought the whole island of Lanai last year for $300 million. So, he lost the equivalent of 11 Hawaiian Islands today.

Meanwhile, trying to make "Money" today, Starbucks, it is raising drink cause for first time in almost two years. The average price hike will be about one percent. Starbucks blames rising rent and labor cost for the increase.

And the Miami heat championship win proving a ratings gold mine for ABC. Nearly 18 percent of you at home watched game seven last night. That is according to Nielsen. It is the second highest rating for an NBA game in 11 years, a sign of the times and congratulations.

So, if you have been following the NSA spy scandal you may wonder how tight the government really is with big tech companies like facebook, for example. Well, a shocking report reveal that actually left to go work for the NSA back in 2010 and evidently, he is not the only big tech exec that's made the move from Silicon Valley to government spy agency.

That brings up a lot of questions and concerns, namely what kinds of info are these ex-tech employees bringing to their new job. With me on this frightening development is managing director of TechnoBuffalo, Roy Choi.

Welcome back to the show, Roy.

ROY CHOI, MANAGING DIRECTOR, TECHNOBUFFALO: Thank you.

FRANCIS: I mean, should we be afraid of this? I mean, this is a guy who was in charge of protecting our own private personal information on facebook and he eventually took the knowledge and the keys of the kingdom and went to go work for an agency that is now spying on us.

CHOI: I think we have to assume that, you know, employees as tech companies like facebook, Google, Skype, they have this information and they're going to go somewhere and may be to the NSA and feed that.

FRANCIS: So, you are basically saying, we have to assume that everything we put online could eventually be handed over to people who are spying on us? And you just have to be satisfied with that?

CHOI: Yes. They have policies in place, but when you turn into reality you will see that information isn't always word is supposed to be. We will claim it is 100 percent locks down, but how many times have we seen leaks weathered his credit card information or online information leaks either accidentally or a hole in the security software or malicious hackers going in and getting this information.

So, I can't say that people are always going to be secure. And you know, I think people are under the assumption when I post something online, it is going to be there for public consumption. But you know, it is beyond that, it is the metadata, it is the stuff you don't necessarily see.

FRANCIS: What will be his motivation for leaving a place like facebook? You have to imagine that at the level he was, he was making a lot of money and owned a lot of stock and did really well. Why would you leave and go and work for the government?

CHOI: Who knows? Maybe it is a greater challenge. Maybe, you know, facebook has been a huge supporter of helping fight crime a couple of years ago. And I am not saying this particular security official, but the most recent security official actually implemented a program where they could actually search through content, so there was anything that is a sexual predator was out there and putting in language that would be a little worry some for law enforcement, they would openly give that information out. And you know, they have actually stated their policy is as long as there is a court order or any type of subpoena they would hand that information freely in order to protect users. And at that point, they were under a lot of pressure to help especially with lots of sexual predators lurking on facebook.

FRANCIS: That's one thing. But you know, when I have asked that question in the past of hackers and the like, why would you go from the private sector where you are making a lot of money to work for the NSA or any government agency for a lot less. They say that they are allowed to do things when you're working for the NSA that you're not allowed to do in regular life, and you are allowed to spy in a way that you can't do for a private company. So you combine sort of that ability and ambition with someone who knows the intimate ins and outs of a facebook or a Google and you get a very powerful government who could spy on us even more than we ever imagined. Your thoughts on that?

CHOI: Definitely. And I think, when we look at, in terms of national security, in terms of our own security, privately, you are going to see the internet as like the next forum, whether that is in a proactive manner or a reactive manner. So, for someone to leave from Silicon Valley, the constraints of, you know, regulations and whatever else, you know, maybe you go to the NSA, maybe you go to another government agency, but you do get that level of freedom to go out and use your talents to make your mark.

FRANCIS: Yes.

Roy, thank you so much for coming on the show. Appreciate your time.

CHOI: Thank you. Appreciate it.

FRANCIS: Up next on "Money," we are going to Jeffrey Skilling. He committed one of the worst acts of corporate fraud in U.S. history. Well, the former Enron CEO is now getting out of prison 10 years ahead of schedule. We are going to explain why this is music to the ears of white- collar criminals everywhere.

Plus, a bipartisan group of senators wants to block U.S. military funding for Syrian rebels. You may like the sound of that, but will we have to spend even more if we don't act now? One of the many top experts breaks down the numbers for us.

Piles of "money" coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MELISSA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: New developments today in the case of convicted white-collar felon, Jeffrey Skilling. The former Enron CEO has served six and half years of a 24-year sentence, so far, for bringing down the world's largest energy trader. It was one of the worst acts of corporate fraud in U.S. history.

But today, his sentence was sliced by 10 years. Meaning, now, he's going to be out in just seven and a half years instead of 17 1/2 years from now. So, what does his short and sentence mean for white-collar criminals? Here with the dish is our go to lawyer, Arthur Aidala.

ARTHUR AIDALA, FOX NEWS LEGAL ANALYST: Dish?

FRANCIS: Dish. Yes.

AIDALA: Is that a legal term?

FRANCIS: It is. You didn't know that, because you're a lawyer. You should know.

AIDALA: -- any Italian food, so I don't know what the dishes (ph) are about.

FRANCIS: What is the deal?

AIDALA: The deal here is this. He appeals -- he gets convicted, gets this huge sentence --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: I mean, he didn't kill anyone.

AIDALA: He didn't kill anyone, but let me double check my map here. $60 billion in Enron stock was rendered worthless. $2 billion in employee pension were rented worthless. It's a lot of guilt (ph).

FRANCIS: Yes.

AIDALA: That's a lot of money going on there. So -- and more importantly that a lot of money, it's a lot of people who got affected. I mean, lives were ruined, lives were destroyed. So, he gets this really rough sentence. He -- (INAUDIBLE) who supposed to go get sentenced and get wiped out, he dies, so that wipes out his conviction. And, he appeals all the way up to the Supreme Court, and the Supreme Court basing the rules in his favor saying one of the ways -- one of the convictions against him was improper.

They go to a lower court about it. Should there be a new trial? Should there be a new trial? The bottom line is, they say that he was sentenced to nine years too many, and for them not to re-appeal, because he could have, the government said look --

FRANCIS: Nine years too many in which -- in what then? Why?

AIDALA: Because the guideline calculations, which is the very complicated way.

FRANCIS: They did the bath rock (ph).

AIDALA: Well, they applied things the wrong way. In federal court unlike state court, to figure someone's sentence, you need like a small calculus degree. It's crazy. And basically, in court, the judges said, you did this the wrong way, you came about this the wrong way, therefore, there's at least nine years that he's got tacked on that shouldn't be tacked on.

FRANCIS: So, are white-collar criminals everywhere rejoining because the scuttlebutt on this all week long has been that the sentences for financial crimes up late. I mean, if you look at (INAUDIBLE). I mean, all of this has been very stiff.

AIDALA: Well, what -- right.

FRANCIS: And is this the beginning of a reduction in the sentences for financial crisis, which as you said, ruined a lot of lives --

AIDALA: A lot of lives.

FRANCIS: -- but in many cases are longer than murder convictions.

AIDALA: Correct. But literally, like a murder conviction, you're really affecting like one person and one family. This affected --

FRANCIS: Right. But they're dead as opposed to I don't have money. I mean, we should rather be alive --

(CROSSTALK)

AIDALA: But there are these charts in the federal law that when you commit a crime, you start off at a very -- a below base level which is like a non-jail sentence. And then depending on how much money was stolen or how much fraud or how much tax evasion, that's what you come up with the numbers. So, if it's just a minimal amount like 100 million, you're at one level.

FRANCIS: Very little. Yes.

AIDALA: When it's 60 billion, you're at the highest level. You're literally off the charts. The United State Supreme Court did say that the way they convicted him under this honest services fraud law, which is a very complicated thing to explain, was not done properly. So, yes, a door has been opened to criminal defendants to tell the government, you need to prosecute us in this way, not in that way. And it may have lightened the load on them. But, you know --

FRANCIS: Sounds like you don't think the original 24 was that unfair (ph), though.

AIDALA: I mean, they did some bad stuff. They hurt a lot of people. They hurt a lot of retired people who are like -- I mean, you go from thinking like, going to bed, thinking I have a half a million dollars in the bank and I'm 80 years old to I have nothing in the bank and I'm 80 years old.

FRANCIS: Yes.

AIDALA: Hello!

FRANCIS: Arthur, thank you so much.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: You did a great job. There's smoke coming out of your ears.

AIDALA: I learn about the dish. I dished it. I knew about the dish. Thank you, folks.

FRANCIS: Turning now to a much more serious topic, the unsettling situation in Syria. All eyes are on the country's reports (ph) on chemical weapons use and see frightening images of escalating violence. Now, some Lawmakers here at home are trying to block any U.S. funding to armed rebels.

Of course, we know the story is about a lot more than money. There's an enormous human toll, but our show is called MONEY, so we're going to focus on that angle. We're going to take a closer look at whether or not it would actually cost us more to get involved now or not.

Joining us now with his take is Zuhdi Jasser, president of the American Islamic Forum for Democracy. Always nice to have you, Zuhdi.

ZUHDI JASSER, AMERICAN ISLAMIC FORUM FOR DEMOCRACY: Thanks, Melissa. It's great to be with you.

FRANCIS: You know, we're trying to break down the cost. As we said, huge human toll, you know, for humanitarian reasons you may or may not want to get involved, but looking at just the dollar part of it, what is the cost of doing nothing at this point?

JASSER: Well, we have two and half years, Melissa, of the revolution to know what that cost is. And just some numbers from Tel Aviv University, it looks like in Jordan, it costs $35 per refugee just to house them per year. So, you're looking right now at three to four million refugees that have been displaced in Syria.

FRANCIS: Who's paying for that?

JASSER: That's the thing. Jordan is paying for some of it, but we're paying a lot of it. We've already paid over half a billion dollars through USAID into the region, and it's looking like the refugees are going to reach six million by the end of the year, and our money is into it.

It's going to be in the billions whether we do, you know, nothing militarily or not, it's going to be -- it's a part of the region that if we're going to continue to try to maintain stability, the humanitarian aid is not only the compassionate thing to do, it has to be done militarily strategically or otherwise the entire region will implode with sectarian violence and our ally in the region. Israel will certainly be threatened.

FRANCIS: If we do something, that is incredibly expensive, already looking at the estimates. A no-fly zone in the first 10 days alone would cost $1.4 billion. And it expands from there, right?

JASSER: Oh, absolutely. And you know, the no-fly zone -- yes, Libya was a bit cheaper, but they're looking -- this is more like Iraq. Syria has a more sophisticated military that would need to be taken out, and somewhere of 50 to 100 million a day, they say. But still, I think the cost and a lot of experts have said this the cost are going to be less, as Michael O'Hanlon (ph) from Brookings said, it's a bargain if we can end this war earlier.

Because look, two and half years have proven this war is going nowhere. Assad maybe winning as far as militarily, but the attrition from the Syrian army continues. It's only how long, how many months or years when Assad will finally fall. And if we want to have a play in the region and be involved in the right side of history and help move them towards, we defeat Assad first as the strategy and second defeat al Qaeda.

If we want to play a role in that, we have to be on the right side of history to fight against the Iran, fight against Hezbollah, et cetera. Not with troops.

FRANCIS: -- on the right side of history and some are arguing that it's too late for that. That early on, we could have been fighting against Hezbollah and Assad. And when we originally saw pictures of children being slaughtered, that was the time to get involved, but we didn't. And now, at this point, al Qaeda and extremists have gotten involved.

On the other side, and it's become now al Qaeda versus Hezbollah, which isn't our fight, neither of those folks are our friends, and we should just stay out of it. That is one of the theories that's out there. I'll give you the last word on why you don't agree with that, if you don't.

JASSER: Well, that calculus of characterizing the opposition of al Qaeda is just not correct. The Syrian population has become more radicalized and they're becoming more, you know, chaotic and committing atrocities, but that's because we've done nothing. If we come to the side of helping the millions -- there's only tens of thousands of al Qaeda -- the millions of Syrians in this opposition, we will help defeat the ultimate source of the radicalization which is Assad.

And remember, Hezbollah, the forms of terror in the Middle East is Iran. So, those on my (ph) conservative side that believe that doing nothing will allow al Qaeda to die, actually, al Qaeda is thriving, Hezbollah is thriving. Terror will thrive without our involvement. So, the question is, which side has less terror? I believe doing something would.

FRANCIS: Zuhdi Jasser, thank you so much for your thoughts tonight. We always appreciate it.

JASSER: Thank you. Appreciate it.

FRANCIS: We have some breaking news right now on Facebook. Let's go to Fox Business' Jo Ling Kent with the latest. Jo Ling, what do you have?

JO LING KENT, FOX BUSINESS: Melissa, Facebook is confirming on their website that a security breach has exposed six million e-mail addresses and telephone numbers. And let me tell you a little bit more of what they're saying on the website.

They found, they said, through their white hat security researching program that they use that, quote, "that may have allowed some of a person's contact information e-mail or phone number to be accessed by people who either had some contact information about the person or some connection to that person."

So, they're saying six million e-mail addresses and telephone numbers were shared, but Facebook was also very quick to note in its statement that no other types of personal or financial information were included and only people on Facebook, not developers or advertisers, had access to this information.

So, certainly, a very alarming security breach has happened at Facebook, and we'll continue to bring you more a little bit later, Melissa.

FRANCIS: Wow. Jo Ling, thanks so much.

All right. Coming up on MONEY, surviving the end of the world sounds tough. Indoor pool, a bowling alley, a golf, maybe it wouldn't be that bad. A California developer is opening the world's largest doomsday shelter. This will be an underground resort. It's fabulous. He's taking reservations. He joins us with all the details, because at the end of the day, the end of the world, it's all about MONEY.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Talk about surviving in style. Vivos Survival Shelter and Resort is the chicest doomsday shelter out there. For a few thousand bucks, you and yours (ph) can be safe from any number of impending disasters. Cozily nestled 100 feet below in Atchison Kansas, and you can live in your shelter in your very own RV -- wow! -- for up to a year. There is big money to be made in the bunker business.

Joining me now is Robert Vicino. He is founder and CEO of Vivos Group and the owner of the fabulous shelter. Thank you so much for coming on.

ROBERT VICINO, VIVOS GROUP FOUNDER AND CEO: It's my honor.

FRANCIS: I understand that this is a space that the army previously used. They auctioned it off. And what gave you the idea to make it into a doomsday shelter?

VICINO: Well, we've been in the shelter business for the last five years building Vivos shelters around the world. And, typically, whenever a government shelter or facility comes up, we try to buy it and then retrofitted and convert it into a modern day blast shelter. This one was auctioned by the GSA and we jumped on it.

FRANCIS: What is it like? What happens when I arrived there?

VICINO: It is a turnkey four-star underground hotel/cruise ship. It's everything you could imagine. It's not just a survival shelter. It is truly a destination resort where you and your family and your children would want to go to many times a year, perhaps, in the middle of the winter where it' s 70 degrees inside this mountain year round. So, you will be very comfortable.

FRANCIS: Do people come even if there's not a disaster by space (ph). Can I come and hang out?

VICINO: Anytime you want. You can't permanently live there, but yes, it's open 24/7 forever. And so, you buy your space and you park your RV there, whatever you're comfortable with, be it a 20-footer or 45-foot motor home for a million dollar. And it's a one-time charge, and you know, it's yours, you're a co-owner of this what would be a billion dollar replacement.

FRANCIS: Does it cost me a million dollars? I mean, I read that it's $1,000 per lineal foot. The average RV is about 30 feet, so that's $30,000, and there's $1,500 charge per person, but I don't know what -- over what period of time. How much would it cost me? I have a husband and two kids, what are you going to charge me?

VICINO: Well, you're the perfect nuclear family.

FRANCIS: Yes. Thank you.

VICINO: And, it would cost no extra charge for any of those family members, the only thing you're paying for is the RV, itself, by the lineal foot. So, if you had a 30-foot RV, it's $30,000 and four children or four people for food, that's a one year food supply. It's another 6,000. So, for $36,000, you've got yourself an investment and a life assurance policy or --

FRANCIS: How many people have signed up, so far? How much money have you made?

VICINO: Well, not enough. We've had 25,000 applications over the last few years. The primary problem has been the cost. People can't afford our other shelters where it's a per person rate as much as $50,000. So, this --

FRANCIS: So, of those 25,000, how many people have locked it in?

VICINO: On this new one, we just announced it last week in or membership, and we've got a few hundred already signed up. So, it's going to happen very quickly. We'll sell out. This one will accommodate only 1,500 RVs or about 5,000 people, which I like to say is almost one in a million people on Earth.

FRANCIS: This one makes me nervous about this. So, you're all the way in Kansas. I'm in New York, for example. What kind of doomsday disaster would come my way that I would have enough time to get there?

VICINO: Oh, let's say a nuke went off in L.A. or in Washington or in the Middle East, or let's say where about to see a major economic meltdown, which could happen any day, as you know, or let's say the earth was rumbling or an asteroid was on its way. Things --

FRANCIS: I would have enough time to get there?

VICINO: It's time to go. And you may go and it may not happen, and so, it's a false alarm just like the fireman goes to the --

FRANCIS: Yes.

VICINO: -- but at least you have somewhere to go versus the other seven billion people on the planet that will have no solution, nowhere to go, and they'll be scrambling. And you don't want to be a part of that mash (ph). You want to go. You want to have a safe haven. You'll be underground in what we call effectively a fortress.

FRANCIS: OK. Robert, thanks for coming on the show. Interesting idea. Sounds like -- I'll be interested to see if it's a good business, if you sell out, because -- I mean, there's a lot to be afraid of these days. I don't know. People want an insurance policy. Thanks for coming on. Keep us posted.

VICINO: My pleasure.

FRANCIS: Here is our MONEY question of the day. How much would you pay for a spot on world's biggest doomsday shelter? Not surprisingly, I got a lot of funny responses to this one, including Less Than Zero. "I'd rather die than live in Kansas." Come on! Come on. Kansas is a nice place. That was mean.

We want to hear from more of you. You can like us on Facebook at acebook.com/MelissaFrancisFox or follow me on Twitter @MelissaAFrancis.

All right. Coming up on MONEY. Oh, bless you, Kanye and Kim. You gave your baby a name even crazier than we thought possible. And there's developing news on what the middle name is, too. We've got it all in "Spare Change." You can never have too many insane celebrities.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: All right. Welcome to "Spare Change." We are joined by Jarrod Guy Randolph and we also have Hitha Prabhakar here. Thanks to both of you for coming on. A little "Spare Change" fun on this Friday.

HITHA PRABHAKAR, RETAIL ANALYST: Thanks for having us.

FRANCIS: All right. First, we are going to look at some birthdays at work. If it is not already bad enough that you're in the office for your birthday, check this out. This birthday card we saw, you literally just check the box next to your name. Can you imagine that, to show your love? I mean, come on. You can't even sign your name anymore.

What would you do if you got this card? You check the box next to your names. You check, you know, best wishes, happy birthday, get hammered on us. I don't know.

PRABHAKAR: I got to be honest with you, this is actually a nicer card than I received from most of my family members for my birthday.

FRANCIS: What?

PRABHAKAR: Yes.

FRANCIS: You need a new family.

(LAUGHTER)

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: What is worse than this card, no card at all or do the cards say does it have so many else's name in it? I mean, what is worse than this card?

PRABHAKAR: Misspelled name.

FRANCIS: Hitha is pretty straightforward. Hitha Prabhakar, I don't want to have to spell on television, but Hitha, I could do.

PRABHAKAR: No one really sign their names either. It was just kind of --

FRANCIS: Really?

PRABHAKAR: Yes.

FRANCIS: Wow.

PRABHAKAR: Yes. So --

FRANCIS: You're going to be in therapy for that for a long time.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Jarrod, what about you?

JARROD GUY RANDOLPH, CORE VICE PRESIDENT: I don't think there was follow-through on that card. It was supposed to lead in the something else, but I mean --

FRANCIS: Like what?

(CROSSTALK)

RANDOLPH: If birthday cards look like that, I can only imagine what the annual holiday bonus looks like.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Yes.

RANDOLPH: So, for me, I'd be a little upset if my co-workers gave that to me.

FRANCIS: OK. So, this is a new case for your iPhone. It doubles as a stun gun to prevent any accidental discharge. Yes, I would hope. Users have to flip two switches before activating the gun. The case sells for 140 bucks. And the co-founder says sales could exceed a million dollars this year.

Is this just a must have or is it a lawsuit waiting to happen? I'm wondering, what happens when you accidentally but dial with your iPhone. That's a stun gun (ph). That would be quite a shock.

PRABHAKAR: Not only is it a lawsuit waiting to happen, it's a disaster waiting to happen. I mean, I can't tell you how many times I get misdialed phones from different people. I misdial (ph) phone. Also, if you're getting attacked, why would you want to on latch (ph) something and then security check this. I mean, wouldn't you want to just kind of go for it and try to protect yourself?

RANDOLPH: I see the value on this product.

FRANCIS: You do?

RANDOLPH: This will be even (ph) my secret weapon. You will buy a $50 million apartment. I'm going to start using this with my client.

(LAUGHTER)

RANDOLPH: I mean, I don't see why not. If this actually became an approved Apple accessory. So --

FRANCIS: What? Really?

RANDOLPH: It's kind of amazing.

FRANCIS: There should be a breathalyzer attached to it.

(CROSSTALK)

RANDOLPH: They're going to come up with that.

PRABHAKAR: Right.

RANDOLPH: And if you go on the website, the pink ones are the ones that have sold out first. I'm just waiting for the camouflage.

FRANCIS: How much is the cost? Does anybody know?

RANDOLPH: I think it's about $140.

FRANCIS: Wow! That's amazing. Well, there's a Christmas gift.

All right. So, the big baby news of the week, a bizarre name given. Reality princess, Kim Kardashian and rapper baby daddy, Kanye West, have chosen the name North, North, for their baby girl. Think about that for a second. The baby's name is Northwest, no middle name. I mean, they're running this child's life or they giving it direction.

PRABHAKAR: All right. We can safely assume that it's not a fan of One Direction, right, the band?

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: OK. All right. I like that. That was good. Jarrod, what do you think about this?

RANDOLPH: The middle name should be Southeast. So, it's north, south, east, west. I mean, I actually can't believe we're talking about this right now.

(LAUGHTER)

RANDOLPH: But think about it, there were other names that could have come up with. Lampshade, soda can. I mean, they could have named it anything.

FRANCIS: Seven, Pepsi. I don't know. All those --

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: One of the worst names ever.

PRABHAKAR: I like the east and west. Wasn't east and west --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: And we wrap up the week. Our own Tom Sullivan has some doubts about the direction of our economy. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TOM SULLIVAN, FOX BUSINESS: Something isn't right about the economy. I'm trying to be positive, and yes, the economy has expanded every quarter going back to 2009. But it's consistently weak growth. The job market, it's also improving, but not enough to soak up all of the new people that are coming into the job market, the young grads and immigrants. And housing, it seems to be doing better. In fact, in some places, there's another price bubble growing.

But, it's because there are two few homes for sale and that's largely because whopping (ph) number, 44 percent of homeowners are either under water or they don't have enough equity to pay a realtor to sell their home, so they sit. And it's the same number, 44 percent of people who told CNN in a poll this week that they are worse off economically now than compared to just one year ago.

The huge portion of the country is still hurting. The markets are nervous about the fed slowing down its artificial pumping of the economy. I get that, but even though I don't like what the fed is done, I don't see the fed making any big changes, and I don't see this fragile economy jumping out of its sick bed anytime soon.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Well, that's true. Thanks, Tom. Be sure to watch "The Tom Sullivan Show" this weekend. You can catch it at 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on Saturday, and on Sunday at 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. Happy Friday, everyone. Thanks to both of you for joining us. Have a great weekend. I'll see you back here on Monday.

END

urn:contentItem:58PV-W8J1-JB20-G121-00000-00Skilling's Sliced Sentence; Surviving In Style; Bernanke Slammed for Bond Buying Statement; Michael Dell vs Carl Icahn Battles in Wall Street; Facebook's Former Security Chief Max Kelly Now Working at NSA2013-06-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:28ZLexisNexisMONEY5:00 PM ESTArthur Aidala, Zuhdi Jasser, Robert Vicino, Hitha Prabhakar, Jarrod Guy Randolph, Roy Choi; Dennis Berman; Jonas Max Ferris; Jack Hough; Pat HowellNEWSFinancial062101cb.230Skilling's Sliced Sentence; Surviving In Style; Bernanke Slammed for Bond Buying Statement; Michael Dell vs Carl Icahn Battles in Wall Street; Facebook's Former Security Chief Max Kelly Now Working at NSAMelissa Francis, Jo Ling Kent, Tom Sullivan

MELISSA FRANCIS, FBN ANCHOR: They said Bernanke never should've opened his mouth this week. With the fed making a financial mess, how to prepare with what is coming next.

Plus, surviving the apocalypse in style. A California developer is opening the world's largest doomsday shelter and resort. Where do I make my reservation? The man behind it joins us.

And who lost "Money" today? One of America's top CEO, it is so much money, it would make John B. Rockefeller cry. Stay tuned to find out who it is.

Because even when they say t is not, it is always about "Money."

It is the end of a very tumultuous week on Wall Street and it is time for some serious crisis management for the fed. So, you are entering the spin zone. Ben Bernanke is getting slam for statements this week about the possibility of easing off the bond buying program which came just two days of the fed chairman was basically fired on the Charlie Rose show. I don't know if you saw this, a lot of moving pieces but we want you to know what you have to do right now to protect yourself in the midst of all of it.

Joining me now is Barron's senior editor, Jack Hough and Pat Howell, CEO of Howell financial group. Welcome back to the show.

Jack, let me start with you. Have the wheels come off the fed here? I mean, it has been quite a week for those guys.

JACK HOUGH, SENIOR EDITOR, BARRON: I'm not sure what the dissent is about. I mean, are we supposed to keep interest rates near zero forever? I mean, at this point, you are trading off this much improvement in the economy versus this much distortion of every kind of asset class investors have a choice of. It is time, isn't it?

FRANCIS: It is time. But that is not really what we're talking about. I mean, what we are talking about is sort of the chaos that ensued this week. For example, I mean, let me play you the sound bite. President Obama basically fired Ben Bernanke in Charlie Rose. And we will get both your reactions on the other side. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think Ben Bernanke has done an outstanding job. Ben Bernanke is a little bit like Bob Mueller, the head of the FBI where he has already stayed a lot longer than he wanted or he was supposed to. But, I think --

CHARLIE ROSE, TV HOST: But if he wanted to be reappointed, you would reappoint him?

OBAMA: He has been outstanding partner along with the White House.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: What? I mean, that is not really a ringing endorsement. Pat, that is like somebody saying, you know, how is your husband? You are like, well, he has been outstanding partner until now.

PATRICIA POWELL, CEO, POWELL FINANCIAL GROUP: Anybody can be a loose cannon, it is just odd it is the president of the United States.

FRANCIS: Is he a loose cannon or was that on purpose? I mean, don't know. There is a lot of negativity there.

POWELL: He is making some telegraphing things too. He is not going to Jackson hole, you know, that was a little odd. I mean, he has been telegraphing things. And a lot of people say that he is tired, this has been exhausting thing, and it was not really -- this is now what he had in mind when he became chairman of the fed.

HOUGH: He was looking at his shoes when he said that, right?

FRANCIS: Right.

HOUGH: I'm not a body language expert, but that says stayed.

FRANCIS: He stayed a lot longer than he was supposed to or he wanted to. I mean, that is pretty harsh. So then, it is not surprising that Ben Bernanke comes out, rocks the boat a bit. I mean, they are all over the place. You have James Bullard, Ben coming out today saying, well maybe, you know, we are going t have more combination down the road if we need it. Basically, going against everything that Ben Bernanke said, which is sort of all over the map. Where does that leave investors?

VICINO: Well, not enough. We've had 25,000 applications over the last few years. The primary problem has been the cost. People can't afford our other shelters where it's a per person rate as much as $50,000. So, this --

FRANCIS: So, of those 25,000, how many people have locked it in?

VICINO: On this new one, we just announced it last week in or membership, and we've got a few hundred already signed up. So, it's going to happen very quickly. We'll sell out. This one will accommodate only 1,500 RVs or about 5,000 people, which I like to say is almost one in a million people on Earth.

FRANCIS: This one makes me nervous about this. So, you're all the way in Kansas. I'm in New York, for example. What kind of doomsday disaster would come my way that I would have enough time to get there?

VICINO: Oh, let's say a nuke went off in L.A. or in Washington or in the Middle East, or let's say where about to see a major economic meltdown, which could happen any day, as you know, or let's say the earth was rumbling or an asteroid was on its way. Things --

FRANCIS: I would have enough time to get there?

VICINO: It's time to go. And you may go and it may not happen, and so, it's a false alarm just like the fireman goes to the --

FRANCIS: Yes.

VICINO: -- but at least you have somewhere to go versus the other seven billion people on the planet that will have no solution, nowhere to go, and they'll be scrambling. And you don't want to be a part of that mash (ph). You want to go. You want to have a safe haven. You'll be underground in what we call effectively a fortress.

FRANCIS: OK. Robert, thanks for coming on the show. Interesting idea. Sounds like -- I'll be interested to see if it's a good business, if you sell out, because -- I mean, there's a lot to be afraid of these days. I don't know. People want an insurance policy. Thanks for coming on. Keep us posted.

VICINO: My pleasure.

FRANCIS: Here is our MONEY question of the day. How much would you pay for a spot on world's biggest doomsday shelter? Not surprisingly, I got a lot of funny responses to this one, including Less Than Zero. "I'd rather die than live in Kansas." Come on! Come on. Kansas is a nice place. That was mean.

We want to hear from more of you. You can like us on Facebook at acebook.com/MelissaFrancisFox or follow me on Twitter @MelissaAFrancis.

All right. Coming up on MONEY. Oh, bless you, Kanye and Kim. You gave your baby a name even crazier than we thought possible. And there's developing news on what the middle name is, too. We've got it all in "Spare Change." You can never have too many insane celebrities.

FRANCIS: All right. Welcome to "Spare Change." We are joined by Jarrod Guy Randolph and we also have Hitha Prabhakar here. Thanks to both of you for coming on. A little "Spare Change" fun on this Friday.

HITHA PRABHAKAR, RETAIL ANALYST: Thanks for having us.

FRANCIS: All right. First, we are going to look at some birthdays at work. If it is not already bad enough that you're in the office for your birthday, check this out. This birthday card we saw, you literally just check the box next to your name. Can you imagine that, to show your love? I mean, come on. You can't even sign your name anymore.

What would you do if you got this card? You check the box next to your names. You check, you know, best wishes, happy birthday, get hammered on us. I don't know.

PRABHAKAR: I got to be honest with you, this is actually a nicer card than I received from most of my family members for my birthday.

FRANCIS: What?

PRABHAKAR: Yes.

FRANCIS: You need a new family.

(LAUGHTER)

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: What is worse than this card, no card at all or do the cards say does it have so many else's name in it? I mean, what is worse than this card?

PRABHAKAR: Misspelled name.

FRANCIS: Hitha is pretty straightforward. Hitha Prabhakar, I don't want to have to spell on television, but Hitha, I could do.

PRABHAKAR: No one really sign their names either. It was just kind of --

FRANCIS: Really?

PRABHAKAR: Yes.

FRANCIS: Wow.

PRABHAKAR: Yes. So --

FRANCIS: You're going to be in therapy for that for a long time.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Jarrod, what about you?

JARROD GUY RANDOLPH, CORE VICE PRESIDENT: I don't think there was follow-through on that card. It was supposed to lead in the something else, but I mean --

FRANCIS: Like what?

(CROSSTALK)

RANDOLPH: If birthday cards look like that, I can only imagine what the annual holiday bonus looks like.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Yes.

RANDOLPH: So, for me, I'd be a little upset if my co-workers gave that to me.

FRANCIS: OK. So, this is a new case for your iPhone. It doubles as a stun gun to prevent any accidental discharge. Yes, I would hope. Users have to flip two switches before activating the gun. The case sells for 140 bucks. And the co-founder says sales could exceed a million dollars this year.

Is this just a must have or is it a lawsuit waiting to happen? I'm wondering, what happens when you accidentally but dial with your iPhone. That's a stun gun (ph). That would be quite a shock.

PRABHAKAR: Not only is it a lawsuit waiting to happen, it's a disaster waiting to happen. I mean, I can't tell you how many times I get misdialed phones from different people. I misdial (ph) phone. Also, if you're getting attacked, why would you want to on latch (ph) something and then security check this. I mean, wouldn't you want to just kind of go for it and try to protect yourself?

RANDOLPH: I see the value on this product.

FRANCIS: You do?

RANDOLPH: This will be even (ph) my secret weapon. You will buy a $50 million apartment. I'm going to start using this with my client.

(LAUGHTER)

RANDOLPH: I mean, I don't see why not. If this actually became an approved Apple accessory. So --

FRANCIS: What? Really?

RANDOLPH: It's kind of amazing.

FRANCIS: There should be a breathalyzer attached to it.

(CROSSTALK)

RANDOLPH: They're going to come up with that.

PRABHAKAR: Right.

RANDOLPH: And if you go on the website, the pink ones are the ones that have sold out first. I'm just waiting for the camouflage.

FRANCIS: How much is the cost? Does anybody know?

RANDOLPH: I think it's about $140.

FRANCIS: Wow! That's amazing. Well, there's a Christmas gift.

All right. So, the big baby news of the week, a bizarre name given. Reality princess, Kim Kardashian and rapper baby daddy, Kanye West, have chosen the name North, North, for their baby girl. Think about that for a second. The baby's name is Northwest, no middle name. I mean, they're running this child's life or they giving it direction.

PRABHAKAR: All right. We can safely assume that it's not a fan of One Direction, right, the band?

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: OK. All right. I like that. That was good. Jarrod, what do you think about this?

RANDOLPH: The middle name should be Southeast. So, it's north, south, east, west. I mean, I actually can't believe we're talking about this right now.

(LAUGHTER)

RANDOLPH: But think about it, there were other names that could have come up with. Lampshade, soda can. I mean, they could have named it anything.

FRANCIS: Seven, Pepsi. I don't know. All those --

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: One of the worst names ever.

PRABHAKAR: I like the east and west. Wasn't east and west --

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: And we wrap up the week. Our own Tom Sullivan has some doubts about the direction of our economy. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TOM SULLIVAN, FOX BUSINESS: Something isn't right about the economy. I'm trying to be positive, and yes, the economy has expanded every quarter going back to 2009. But it's consistently weak growth. The job market, it's also improving, but not enough to soak up all of the new people that are coming into the job market, the young grads and immigrants. And housing, it seems to be doing better. In fact, in some places, there's another price bubble growing.

But, it's because there are two few homes for sale and that's largely because whopping (ph) number, 44 percent of homeowners are either under water or they don't have enough equity to pay a realtor to sell their home, so they sit. And it's the same number, 44 percent of people who told CNN in a poll this week that they are worse off economically now than compared to just one year ago.

The huge portion of the country is still hurting. The markets are nervous about the fed slowing down its artificial pumping of the economy. I get that, but even though I don't like what the fed is done, I don't see the fed making any big changes, and I don't see this fragile economy jumping out of its sick bed anytime soon.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Well, that's true. Thanks, Tom. Be sure to watch "The Tom Sullivan Show" this weekend. You can catch it at 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on Saturday, and on Sunday at 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. Happy Friday, everyone. Thanks to both of you for joining us. Have a great weekend. I'll see you back here on Monday.
