urn:contentItem:5TYF-1XK1-F0JP-W0XG-00000-00Slay the tech dragons2018-12-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:28ZLexisNexis13OPINIONPg. 13Slay the tech dragonsAnna Caldwell

Scott Morrison is hoping a win in his brewing fight with Facebook and Google will reverse his poll slide and show that his party can stand up for the little guy

Scott Morrison has picked a fight even bigger than his current foes of Bill Shorten and sagging poll numbers.

And what's at stake is nothing smaller, really, than the question of who controls the future and all the information in it: individual Australians, or hi-tech behemoths like Google and Facebook who, from their Silicon Valley headquarters, have the power to shape the news, move markets and even influence elections.

While the battle is a big one, it is also a smart choice for a PM who needs to reset the narrative around his leadership and party.

By painting a target on billion-dollar corporations and claiming to stand up for ordinary Australians who feel increasingly beleaguered by the intrusive and downright creepy behaviour of the tech giants, Morrison could create a counter-narrative to some of his party's big-end-of-town image.

The Prime Minister may even manage to defuse some of Labor's attack lines - which dogged Malcolm Turnbull before Morrison - about what they say is the Liberals' too-cozy relationship with, as Shorten never tires of reminding anyone who will listen, "the big end of town".

This week Morrison told me in an interview that he was going to put the tech giants on notice, saying "governments, countries, prime ministers (and) treasurers have to stand up to these guys and say 'you're very welcome here but you don't get to come with a leave pass'." In no uncertain terms, Morrison says, "if they're not serving people I will step in".

Morrison is conscious that muscling up against big companies rubs some of his Liberal colleagues the wrong way.

But Morrison was at pains to point out to me that he was not taking an anti-Liberal position. Rather he believes that "over time the balance has shifted more and more in favour of the big companies".

"I'm not going to get intimidated when they say 'You're not a real Liberal and you just want to introduce more regulations on companies'," he says.

Morrison added that it was only when governments stood up to behemoths like banks and electricity companies that they made better offers. The same must be assumed of tech companies, who use our data and our lives as their own money-making devices.

If we expect the tech giants to treat customers and business in our country fairly we must stand up to them. And this needs to be a political solution.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's landmark preliminary report into the local operations of Facebook and Google has been a good start.

One of the agency's key proposals is for closer scrutiny by a government agency. The final ACCC report is not due until June 3 - after the federal election. But if he wants to take on this fight, Morrison will have to take steps sooner than that.

Strategists close to Morrison see the impact of Facebook and Google as a problem that seeps into households, families and businesses across the country.

It may not feel like a bread and -butter political issue, but in fact the creep of the tech giants into modern Australia transcends class, culture and geography.

If the government can sell the battle right - a challenge in itself - a war with tech titans could be a topic that speaks to everyday mums and dads who moan that "Facebook is listening to them" and taunting them with ads.

It's certainly a topic that speaks to small businesses, who are edged out by algorithms they can't conquer.

And it's a topic that speaks to simply anyone who is affronted by international companies making money out of Australians' data and operating on their own rules with no transparency.

Morrison's team is conscious of this. I've been told the PM is also planning to put greater focus on the safety of children on these online sites in coming months.

Those close to Morrison remark that he is a decisive and fast-acting Prime Minister - a man who wants to get things done.

In recent weeks alone that has been evident as he tackled the seemingly gargantuan problem of the revolving door of leaders in his own party, in a generational shift that will change how the Liberals back a leader.

In the final week of Parliament he also secured the passage of major encryption laws that also upset the big tech companies, and the big stick energy divestment legislation.

We don't know yet if this get-stuff-done approach will ever translate in the polls.

But the simple fact that Morrison may only have months left in the job is spurring him to not waste a second.

Morrison is right to put the tech companies on notice.And with time ticking he should stick to his playbook and take action against them sooner rather than later.

urn:contentItem:5F5X-4WV1-DYY4-30PN-00000-00Sleek science fiction dares to ask difficult questions2015-01-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:27ZLexisNexisENTS:FILMPg. 27Sleek science fiction dares to ask difficult questionsNigel Powlson

AFTER Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey baffled and dazzled audiences in equal measure in 1968, Hollywood briefly took sci-fi seriously.

There was a string of thought-provoking, intelligent movies that tackled issues such as over-population and the advancement of technology and questioned our humanity.

Silent Running, THX 1138, The Andromeda Strain, Soylent Green and Solaris immediately spring to mind.

But then Star Wars arrived and suddenly sci-fi flicks catered for a blockbuster audience more keen on seeing robots bashing each other than contemplating their lack of humanity.

Only occasionally has that early 1970s aesthetic threatened to return and, when it has, audiences have often stayed away (a pity for films like George Clooney's under-rated remake of Solaris).

Even Blade Runner, the most influential and ground-breaking of those movies, was considered a failure on its initial release, confounding an audience that expected Harrison Ford to do a variation on Hans Solo. It was only in hindsight that Blade Runner has taken on classic status.

The threads opened up by Blade Runner are picked up in Ex Machina, Alex Garland's telling exploration of artificial intelligence that has sleek, clinical good looks that could have come from the early 1970s but which have been deployed to explore very modern concerns.

Domhnall Gleeson plays a talented computer programmer working for an invasive technology company run by a brilliant and elusive technocrat (Oscar Isaac).

Gleeson wins an in-house lottery to travel to Isaac's impossibly remote home to undertake a special assignment for his boss.

He arrives in the back of beyond to find Isaac partying solo in a house that's part hi-tech lab and part prison - Gleeson gets a key card that allows him in but also keeps him out of most of the complex.

His mission is to perform the Turing Test on a cyborg that Isaac has created, with the aim of establishing whether or not the android has enough intelligence and awareness to make a human unsure whether they are dealing with a real or artificial life-form.

The film essentially breaks down into a series of electric verbal confrontations between Gleeson and the robot and Gleeson and Isaac.

The artificial life form comes with the hands and face of a young woman with the name Ava and Gleeson is quickly seduced by her disarming 'personality'. That's effectively achieved by Alicia Vikander, whose movements and language expertly straddle the line between the real and unreal.

Swedish actress Vikander is flavour of the month at the moment (she can also be seen in Testament of Youth) and it's not hard to see why - she has a strong screen presence and an adaptability that's going to make her much in demand.

Gleeson, who was adept at romantic comedy in About Time, is the nominal star of the film but plays second fiddle to both Vikander and the impressive Isaac.

Indeed, Isaac's is perhaps the most telling performance in the film.

As the tech genius with enough wealth to make even the most implausible ambitions possible, he's far from a typical Frankenstein figure - his justifications of his experiments are not only convincing but disconcerting and his performance gives the movie a chilling edge.

This is Garland's directorial debut but he's been screenwriter on a string of compelling movies, most notably working with Danny Boyle (The Beach, 28 Days Later and Sunshine).

But the tone of Ex Machina mostly echoes his adaptation of Never Let Me Go.

Here, as writer and director, he's in perfect position to ensure all his ideas are fully explored.

That's not just how far we should push the artificial intelligence envelope and what the consequences might be, but also the danger of the power that rests with the big tech companies and how they are above regulation and government intervention.

Isaac's wealth was generated by Bluebook, an all-pervading mix of Facebook and Google, that dominates the internet and harvests our personal information to use for whatever ends it deems fit.

This future is certainly both imaginable and not far distant.

Garland also remembers that he has a mass audience to please and makes us uneasy voyeurs of his occasionally unclothed female androids.

Nudity and sexual frissons are the staples of exploitation films but few are brave enough to question what they are doing within the film.

Gleeson's character comes straight out and asks Isaac why he chose to sexualise his cyborg and why Ava had to be so attractive?

Isaac's answer is only partially satisfactory but it's a brave question to ask and part of the reason you walk out of the cinema with plenty to think about.

There's not too many movies that will unsettle and agitate you as Ex Machina does and equally few that almost immediately demand a second viewing.
